comment.narrative:
1.1.1. The activity completed in 2017, the results of the needs assessment was used for the development of the programmatic framework of the Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund (MPHSTF) for Aral Sea region and Regional Development Strategy for Karakalpakstan.
1.1.2. The risk assessment report based on the results of the needs assessment produced. 1000 copies (500 in English, 500 in Russian) of summary version, 700 (350 in English, 350 in Russian) copies of full version of the needs assessment report has been printed out in June 2018. Needs assessment reports have been widely distributed to around 300 participants of International Aral Sea Conference held on June 7-8, 2018, shared with other events of the Programme including at the Side Event to launch the MPHSTF, which was held on 27 November 2018, at the UN HQs.
1.1.4. The web-portal with database has been developed and is currently functional. Under joint efforts of AGPF, UNFPA and UNDP, the IT company has developed the database – an open information web-site on the ecological and demographic situation in the Aral Sea region. The set of statistical data for the database pertaining the Khorezm region and Republic of Karakalpakstan has been compiled and uploaded to the website. The platform is available at http://aral.mptf.uz , and it will be also utilized at the work of the MPSHTF for the Aral Sea region.
1.2.1. The mapping is integral part of the activity 1.1.2. The final version of report on Needs assessment survey and socio-economic and ecological maps (Atlas) were developed by Institute for Social Research in 2017. The map product was also presented as part of the Needs Assessment results presentation. Socio-economic maps are revised taking into account HS approach/concept and finalized for further publication. The maps were used in different presentations of the UN JP and meetings with donors in order to visualize the socio-economic and environmental issues of the Aral Sea region.
1.2.2. Draft Programmatic Framework/Strategy was drafted consolidating the inputs from Inter-Agency Government Working Group (IAWG), International Consultant and shared with UN MPTF Office and the Government of Uzbekistan for further comments in March 2018. After receiving comments and proposals from UN MPTF Office, a draft Strategy/Programmatic framework was discussed with the IAWG and representatives of other key ministries and revised in cooperation with International Consultant. The revised 2nd draft of the Strategy was approved by the UN MPTF Office and Government in November 2018, that was baseline for the launch of the MPHSTF. In addition, the Regional Development Strategy for Karakalpakstan was developed using also the findings of the needs assessment, and presented to partners at the regional level, meantime the RDS is in the process of printing.
1.2.3. As part of the Strategy formulation, group of consultants were recruited, who have done the on-job training to the specialists of the relevant ministries/agencies on regional and local planning during the second half of 2018. In addition, the process of the RDS formulation and findings of the RDS were presented to over 100 representatives of the different line government ministries, agencies and Council of Ministers of Karakalpakstan.
1.2.4. A group of consultants from the Center of Economic Research has been recruited to formulate the Regional Development Strategy for Karakalpakstan. The group of experts has conducted field works on data collection necessary for the Strategy development. The draft Regional Development Strategy has been presented to the regional partners (NAPU - The National Project Management Agency under the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan, Council of Ministers of the Republic of Karakalpakstan, Center for Economic Research, etc.) at the meeting hall of the Council of Ministers of Karakalpakstan for inputs and further finalization. The Regional Development Strategy has been finalized and publication of the Strategy is under process. In addition, The Investment Guide for Karakalpakstan has been developed in cooperation with the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in alignment with the Council of Ministers and Joqargi Kenges of the Republic of Karakalpakstan. The strategic priorities necessary for investment to support the economic and food security of the UN JP target districts have been elaborated in the Investment Guide.
1.2.5. The findings of the Regional Development Strategy will be integrated into regional and district level state programs by relevant ministries to formulate evidence based targeted action plans for socio-economic development of the region. This part of the activities will be conducted next year.
1.2.6. As part of the Strategy formulation, group of consultants were recruited, who have done the on-job training to the specialists of the relevant ministries/agencies on financial management, Budget Planning and Execution.
1.2.7. Joint Letter of Appeal in June 2018 (UN RC and the Minister of Economy) was sent to donors’ community and diplomatic corps calling to join efforts and mobilize resources under the Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for Aral Sea region. During the Aral Sea Conference held in Jun 7-8, 2018 (over 300 participants), the development partners were shared information about the upcoming Fund through (i) the pre-briefing for donor community with participation of over 30 representatives of different organizations in the UNDP CO, and (ii) presentations about the UN efforts and modalities of the upcoming MPHSTF by UN RC in Uzbekistan and UN MPTF HQ Portfolio Manager. In accordance with the Roadmap on the establishment of MPTF for Aral Sea region, a series of negotiations of the respective government officials with the representatives of potential multilateral & bilateral donors and IFIs were conducted in January-May 2018 to brief them with current activities and resource mobilization purposes. A High Level Event on presentation of MPHSTF for the Aral Sea region conducted at the UN HQ in New York (Governments of Japan, Nigeria Norway, UN MPTF Office, UN HS Unit and UNDP are co-organizers of the event) on 27 November 2018, as part of the awareness raising and resource mobilization activities of the project Communication Strategy. More than 200 people attended the event. Permanent representatives of Japan, Turkey, Kazakhstan, Nigeria and Algeria expressed strong support statements to the MPHSTF. The Government of Uzbekistan has announced about its financial contribution to the Fund and at the end of the meeting signed the Standard Administrative Arrangement with the UN MPTF Office (for USD 6.5 mln). In addition, the representative of Norway has pledged USD 1.2 million to the MPHSTF.
1.3.1. (a) [17] Community Development Plans have been developed in consultation with the local residents from Muynak, Takhtakupir and Shumanay districts in 2018. [17] Initiative Groups have been created in those communities and [336] (40% female) community residents enhanced skills in the capacity building trainings on Human Security approach, problem identification, project formulation, resource management, M&E of the social infrastructure projects and SDGs.
1.3.1. (b) Based on CDP formulation process in line with 1.3.1 (a) above, [14] social infrastructure projects (on installation of power transformer stations, on clean drinking water supply and projects on school reconstruction) have been completed with overall number of 8,457 people (52% females) beneficiaries in target districts. Currently, the transfer process of the projects is underway. In addition, the Programme has involved JICA Alumni in developing small-scale pilot project. Upon the JICA Country Office review, 1 proposal on provision of school furniture for primary school (worth of US $ 4000) in Adai community of Muynak, which was constructed with the support of the project was approved and implemented.
1.3.2. (a) [9] (3 initiated by female) innovative business projects initiated in 2018 is fully functional creating [38] job places (out of which [16] for females) in Muynak, Takhtakupir and Shumanay districts (including 2 demonstration plots on bee farming in Takhktakupir district, milk processing workshop with the network of more than 150 households, food storage warehouse with the capacity of 100 tones and shoe manufacturing workshop, camel wool processing workshop, small guest house and bakery premises).
1.3.2. (b) [45] rural women in target districts trained on business planning and increased their knowledge to design business proposals, existing preferences, taxation issues, how to obtain loans, how to begin a business and ways to identify the target audience through marketing research jointly with the Karakalpakstan Branch of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, the Youth Union, Women’s Committee. More capacity building activities are planned for the next reporting period.
In addition, [30] rural women from Takhtakupyr and Muynak districts improved their knowledge and skills in handicraft skills development. In close cooperation with the Womens Committee of Karakalpakstan, master-classes were organized in order to develop and strengthen knowledge in the field of souvenirs making with low investment requirements and with usage of natural resources available in the region, based on traditional skills and ensured the promotion of sustainable cultural and national heritage of Karakalpakstan. The activities introduced new approaches to business, ensured the involvement of women in the business sector through creating alternative income generation opportunities in the communities. The master-classes helped to open ways for acquiring skills in running the business, selling finished products, attracting potential customers and finding sales channels. Please, see also 1.3.3 (a) for trainings on effective use of water and land.
1.3.2. (c) Capacity building activities from 27th to 29th of November have been conducted by MASHAV experts in the field of advanced and effective methods of irrigation. Participants of the training program consisted of [45] specialists from: Ministry of Agriculture, Ministry of Water Resources, Council of Farmers and Households and specialists of water and land users of the target districts and beyond. Training elaborated on effective use of water and land resources in the wake of water scarcity and management of agriculture under unfavorable weather conditions.
1.3.3. (a) In consultation with the Ministry of Water Resources (former Basin Management Board) of the Republic of Karakalpakstan, the regional training center was established through the full renovation and provision of the all necessary equipment and furniture for the Razvilka hydro-point (due to location in more central place and increased number of hydraulic structures and water measuring points). [6] water outlets installed to enhance the irrigation infrastructure within the “Kyanishjarma” irrigation canal.
1.3.3. (b) [30] dispatch point specialists from Nukus, Karaozek and Takhtakopir districts have been trained on “Alignment of the dispatch service operation, monitoring the activity of the irrigation management posts, and procedures for establishing the water measuring posts”, which has been held on August 17, 2018 at the newly renovated Razvilka hydro-point building conference room.
1.3.3. (c) [68] specialists in water management sector and local farmers have undergone a field-based training entitled “Adaptation of farming enterprises to water shortage conditions by applying water saving technologies”, organized at Field Farmers School (FFS), located at “Gulziyba Reyim” farming enterprise, Karaozek district of the Republic of Karakalpakstan. The training was conducted within the frame of SDC funded National Water Resources Management Project in Uzbekistan (NWRMP). Amongst participants, 15 specialists and farmers were invited from the Karaozek district and 53 beneficiaries came from Chimbay and Takhtakopir districts of Karaklpakstan. Training participants increased skills and knowledge about the traditional and modern methods of irrigating the agricultural crops, methods of identifying importance of irrigation by checking the soil humidity, as well as measuring tools. During the training, a demonstration sessions were also held on application of flexible irrigation kit, a black filming on the cotton rows and bending film tubes for rational irrigation of cotton fields in scarce water conditions. On September 6-8, 2018, under the initiative of the UNDP and Adaptation Fund Project “Developing climate resilience of farming communities in the drought prone parts of Uzbekistan”, a group of specialists from Kazakhstan Fund for Developing Social Initiatives have visited the Aral Sea region and organized a practical dialogue workshop “Creating an awareness mechanism and initiating the introduction of resource and water-saving technologies by local communities in arid climate conditions” at the Nukus branch of the Tashkent State Agrarian University. During this 4 days training workshop over 30 participants from local pasture societies, colleges and university students studied the advantages of resource and water saving technologies and practical implementation of ‘green technologies’ at grassroots level. 5 specialists of the Ministry of Water Resources have also taken part in the training with the purpose of further disseminate the acquired knowledge to the members of Water Consumers’ Associations at the target districts.
1.3.3. (d) The project team had series of consultation meetings with the Ministry of Public Utilities, Tuyemoyin Water Supply Management Board, Takhtakopir district Khokimiyat and representatives of communities on identification of project site to implement drinking water supply project. As per the meeting and site assessment outcome, it was recommended to implement water supply project in Dawqara community of Takhtakopir district, which is located 22 km away from district center. The project will benefit to overall population of 1476 people, 270 households. The community has a secondary school (333 schoolchildren, 73 school staff), a primary healthcare point (serves 877 households, 4368 inhabitants; 16 health staff, 9 technical staff) and a kindergarten (50 children) that will benefit from the drinking water project. The project team contracted project institute to develop project estimation documents and received raw water analysis from Sanitation Epidemic Surveillance Center. Technical specifications for water treatment equipment and bidding announced for (i) supply and delivery of water treatment equipment and (ii) reconstruction of Water Distribution System “Dawqara” based on project estimation documents. On September 21, 2018, two local companies contracted for reconstruction of the water distribution system, and for supply and installation of water purification equipment. The water purification equipment has been delivered and installed, 2500 m polyethylene water pipeline installed and connected to network. The reconstruction works of the water distribution system is at final stage and it is expected to provide community access to clean drinking water by December 20, 2018. The project had challenge in replication of RWSS model to establish a Drinking Water Organization (DWO). The Ministry of Public Housing and Utility Services has agreed to establish DWOs only if the project will construct a new water distribution center arguing that existing water distribution facilities are kept under the balance of the Ministry which will create conflict of interest with DWOs on property rights. Considering the fact that the construction of new water distribution facility exceeds the allocated project budget, it was agreed not to replicate the DWO model under this project frame. The project team has conducted community mobilization activities among target beneficiaries on implementation of community contribution to maintain household connection. In addition, National Consultant on Community Health conducted series of trainings on Sanitation and Hygiene for community people.
1.3.3. (e) Within the frame of project “Improving Access to Drinking Water Supply for the Rural Communities in the Aral Sea Region”, funded by the New World Programme of the Coca-Cola Foundation, Makpalkol community in Takhtakopir district has been selected as a project site. Reconstruction of water distribution center with replacement of water purification equipment in the facility are at final stage of completion. The total number of beneficiaries are 1948 rural inhabitants. The construction of water pipelines in the community has been completed. Representatives of the Procurement Unit from UNDP CO have visited the project site for monitoring of the process of the project implementation, the project is to be completed on 20th December 2018. Water, sanitation and hygiene workshops have been conducted for the local communities with involvement of a local expert. The overall number of participants exceeds 3000 people. A newspaper article has been published in the district newspaper on conducted hygiene and sanitation workshops.
1.6.1. Comprehensive M&E Framework and monitoring tools have been developed and in place. The programme mid-term evaluation (MTE) has been conducted by evaluation team (1 international and 1 national consultant) during July-September period. Based on MTE findings, MTE Report provided with 8 key recommendations. UN JP team has developed Management Response Plan as per the MTE recommendations with specific actions and timeframes, that are being conducted. Impact assessment conducted by National Consultant on Community Development. The assessment captured the best practices and lessons learned on the application of the human security approach in selected 6 project sites on social infrastructure and income generation community projects. Overall, 6 Focus Group Discussions and 9 key informant interviews conducted. The FGDs were targeted at learning the situation prior to implementation of project, changes, number of people benefited from the project, the contribution of the community, the impact of the project to the daily life of beneficiaries, the challenges occurred during project implementation and so on. The impact assessment findings ensured that community residents participation in UNDP projects and community mobilization workshops have raised the awareness of the population on human security concepts and SDGs, the implemented projects have produced their fruits and already positively affecting the social infrastructure as well as the economic conditions of the communities.
1.6.2. Town hall meetings conducted in 15 communities of 3 target districts. Team Leader on Community resilience building, project engineer and community mobilization specialist have discussed with community members their needs in the town hall meetings. Community members have taken an active participation in identification and formulation of community infrastructure projects in the community. Results of needs assessment have been shared with representatives of government institutions in target districts and discussions held on ways of improving the human security needs of population on the ground.
1.6.3 Based on impact assessment findings, the consultant has developed 6 success stories about implemented projects. These success stories depict the past and present living conditions of people in affected communities. The programme has developed a brochure replicating these success stories and visualizing the overall impact of projects in bright photos.
1.6.4. Internal desk review of current situation with donor assistance in Uzbekistan, in particular to Aral Sea region has been conducted to identify best practices and challenges in implementing aid projects. The review findings well incorporated into the Development Strategy/ToR for Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for Aral Sea region that is developed in accordance with the requirements of the UN MPTF Office and taking into consideration Government’s Development Agenda of the region reflected in the Programmatic and Institutional (programmatic framework) Framework for the Aral Sea region. It was endorsed by the Government, UN MPTF Office and UN Agencies and presented at the High Level Event at the UN HQs in New York.
1.7.1. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.2. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.3. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.4. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.5. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.6. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
1.7.7. Baseline Needs Assessment was conducted in August-September, 2018. Assessment Report on the current status and demand for IT equipment and internet connectivity was prepared. Based on the report findings, a list of priority equipment has been compiled.
1.7.8. Business process re-engineering was carried in regards to the public services related to “a birth of child” (issuance of birth registration, payment of social allowance, registering at a local policlinic etc.) and “retirement” (applying for a state pension). Draft administrative regulations have been prepared for a “joined-up”, accessible, affordable public services, which will significantly reduce time and efforts to receive the services. “Joining-up” services will also make receiving different services from different agencies in one place filling out one document possible. The data will be shared with different agencies. The Council of Ministers of the Republic of Karakalpakstan and the Agency for Public Services have proposed to equip the Nukus city and Kungrad district Public services centers (PSC). Nukus city PSC serves the biggest number of clients (serving around 1000 clients per day), while Kungrad district is the largest district in Uzbekistan, covering almost 10% of the country’s area.
1.7.9. Currently, procurement process for equipping the Nukus city PSC with electronic queue management system is ongoing. It is expected the contracts will be signed with vendors before 2019. Procurement of other equipment for Kungrad district PSC is planned for 1Q of 2019.
1.7.10. In pursuance of the national action plan to implement the recommendations of the UN Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), the Womens Committee of the Republic of Uzbekistan as part of the gender disaggregated statistics component of the joint project with UNDP “Womens Empowerment to Participate in Public Administration and increase their activity in the socio-economic life ”on December 17, 2018 organized a round table on the topic“ Introduction of gender-disaggregated statistics in Uzbekistan in accordance with the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women ”. The main purpose of the round table is to discuss the results of introducing gender-disaggregated statistics in Uzbekistan in accordance with the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and the prospects for further replenishing statistics with new data.
1.7.11. Within the UNDP FW component 4 “Women empowerment activities for local gender-responsive development initiatives, public participation of women and innovations targeting the needs of local women” jointly with Women’s committee, two UNDP projects (UNDP WEP and Joint Programme) supported the Regional Women’s Committee in establishing the Center for Rehabilitation and Adaptation of Victims of Violence and Prevention of Suicides in Nukus city. In order to support the State Strategy on promotion of womens rights and opportunities, the center will serve as a supportive shelter to provide social, medical, psychological and legal support to women of the region. Shelters can also contribute to awareness-raising and social change as part of broader efforts to empower women, to strengthen the family well-being, and ensure family’s further prosperity. The UNDP FW has contributed over $10,000 for this center through procuring necessary equipment including computers, air-conditioners, video surveillance system, TV sets, some furniture, washing machine, fridge, etc.
1.7.12. [4] Innovative business projects (in service delivery, food processing, craft) have been selected for funding from the Muynak and Shumanay districts; the procurement of necessary equipment/items/furniture is on process; Contract signed with suppliers for 3 projects on tea house, photo salon and stomatology room projects. Bidding process ongoing for woolen made products business project. All these [4] business projects will create more than [13] work places for rural women.
1.7.13. [1] community infrastructure project identified to provide access for quality drinking water for over 300 rural inhabitants in Shumanay district. Local construction company has been contracted and installation works of water pipeline network has been completed and over 300 people were provided access to clean drinking water.
1.7.14. The opening and inauguration of the Consultation Center established in Nukus, Karakalpakstan for rehabilitation and adaptation of victims from violence and prevention of suicide, was widely covered by national and regional TV as well as other outlets. The documenting best-practices will be conducted next year.
1.7.15. Planned for Quarter 1&2, 2019.
2.1.1. The institutional aspects of the international donor assistance in Uzbekistan and in the Aral Sea region in particular, were analyzed, the report has been prepared. The final version of the MPHSTF in Uzbekistan was prepared by the International Consultant on MPHSTF Establishment in October – November, 2018 in coordination with UN MPTF office. The ToR was agreed among MPHSTF Participating UN organizations (PUNOs) and with the Government of Uzbekistan. The ToR constitutes an integral and underlying part of the MOU between the PUNOs and UN MPTF office (MPHSTF Administrative Agent), signing of which between the above mentioned agencies marks an official launch of the Trust Fund.
2.1.2. [1] Visit of delegation group – participants of the International Conference “Joint Actions to Mitigate the Consequences of the Aral Catastrophe: New Approaches, Innovative Solutions, Investments” to Karakalpakstan (June 7, 2018) was organized comprising of the 170 representatives from diplomatic missions, international organizations focused on environmental issues, government ministries, mass media agencies. The delegation group visited Muynak district and were introduced with the consequences of the Aral Sea Crisis and visited the Muynak Ecological Museum. Mr. Yukio Takasu, UN SG’s Special Adviser on Human Security was also part of delegation. During the conference in Tashkent, presentation on the MPHTSF and its advantages was provided by UN to increase the awareness of the development partners on the Fund’s advantage and seek for cooperation. Number of bilateral meetings of Mr. Yukio Takasu, UN SG’s Special Adviser on Human Security was held with the representatives of the WB, EU Delegation, JICA, Embassies of South Korea, Japan, Swiss to emphases on the importance of joint work within the upcoming Fund. The High Level Event on presentation of the MPHSTF was held on the margins of the 73rd session of the UN GA. The UN Secretary General, high level Uzbekistan government officials, more than 80 Heads of states and bilateral and multilateral organizations, UN Permanent Representatives were invited to the Event. The UN Secretary General and Uzbekistan Deputy Prime Minister made opening remarks with Mr. Yukio Takasu moderating the Event. Preconditions for establishing MPHSTF along with lessons and achievements/best practices from the first UN Joint Program and current UN Joint Program “Building the resilience of communities affected by the Aral Sea crises through Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea” was presented to the participants of the Event. An official launch of the MPHSTF was announced during the Event with Government of Norway being the first country to make an official 1.2 mln. USD worth contribution pledge to the Trust Fund. The Government of Uzbekistan signed Standard Administrative Arrangement with UN MPTF office on its allocation to the Trust Fund to tune of 6.5 mln. USD.
2.1.3 The Action plan on preparation and conducting presentation of the Multi-Partner Human Security Trust Fund for the Aral Sea region (MPHSTF) being established under the aegis of the United Nations approved (#05/1-2110 dated July 24, 2018) by the Prime Minister of the Republic of Uzbekistan. Besides, Decision of the Prime Minister of the Republic of Uzbekistan endorsed on October 12, 2018 on preparation for the presentation of MPHSTF at the High-level event in UN HQ (November 27, 2018) and Government contribution to the Fund. The Ministry of Economy has approved the ToR for the MPHSTF, that resulted in the official launch presentation of the MPHSTF at the UN HQ on 27 November 2018. Meantime, the Action plan to accelerate the work of the MPHSTF is in the process of approval by the Cabinet of Ministers of Uzbekistan.
2.2.1. Consultations with the UN MPTF office on governance and financial structure as well as on other operational aspects of the MPHSF have been launched. Mission from UN MPTF (Ms. Mari Matsumoto - Portfolio Manager) to Uzbekistan organized on June 4-8, 2018, where number of meetings were held with government partners to agree on the institutional aspects of the Fund. The draft of the Operational manual on running the MPSHTF is prepared.
2.2.2. The Roadmap on establishment of MPTF for Aral Sea region approved (#02/1-248 dated January 16, 2018) by the Prime Minister of the Republic of Uzbekistan. The governance structure of the MPHSTF for Aral Sea region is being defined in consultation with the MPTF Office.
2.3.1 The Standard administrative arrangements between UN MPTF office and donors have been developed based on UN MPTF office templates. The Government of Uzbekistan has announced about its financial contribution to the Fund and signed the Standard Administrative Arrangement with the UN MPTF Office (for USD 6.5 mln). The MOU on the establishment of the MPHSTF for the Aral Sea region was signed by the UN MPTF Office and the five participating UN agencies (UNDP, UNFPA, UNICEF, UNESCO and UNODC), meaning the that the Fund is established.
2.3.2 The first meeting of the MPHSTF Steering Committee is planned for early next week, where among others the organizational aspects of the MPHSTF will be discussed and agreed.
2.4.1 Training materials on Human Security Concept in Russian/Uzbek languages were designed and disseminated at national level in collaboration with the experts from the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Uzbekistan and involvement of International Consultant (Human Security expert). Training course has been conducted to the attendees of the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Uzbekistan on Human Security approach with practical examples from the UN Joint Programme activities at the Aral Sea region. The overall number of attendees 70 listeners of the Academy for Public Administration. Hand-outs with presentation on Human Security Concept have been distributed to the participants.
2.4.2. Training materials on Human Security Concept were translated into Russian/Uzbek languages.
2.4.3. In April 2018, a series of sessions on job sessions HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent to the members of the Inter-agency working group, which is assigned to work on establishing the MPHSTF.
2.4.4. In April 2018, a series of sessions on HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent for the specialists of UN agencies in Uzbekistan and UNDP projects personnel.
2.4.5. In April 2018, a series of sessions on HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent for the specialists of projects personnel.
2.4.6. In April 2018, a series of on-job sessions on HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent to the members of the Inter-agency working group, which is assigned to work on establishing the MPHSTF. Training course has been conducted to the attendees of the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Uzbekistan on Human Security approach with practical examples from the UN Joint Programme activities at the Aral Sea region. The overall number of attendees 70 listeners of the Academy for Public Administration. Hand-outs with presentation on Human Security Concept have been distributed to the participants.
2.5.1. In line with the Communication strategy developed by the Programme, the key activities and events were actively promoted through various mass media sources, including national television and radio broadcastings, print media (newspapers and magazines), internet resources (sites of news agencies, official sites of organizations, social media platforms and blogs with a necessary target audience). Various seminars and outreach sessions, workshops and roundtables, brochure, Post Show Reports, newsletter, one-pagers, infographic, calendar, video and audio interviews, as well as a documentary helped to raise awareness about the profile of the Programme. Moreover, to increase public awareness on the Joint Programme and its activities with focus on the human security concept tailored outreach instruments were used to various partner categories to ensure the greater effect: government, international community, population (national level), mass media, beneficiaries, expert community, and business.
2.5.2. In April 2018, a series of on-job sessions on HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent to the members of the Inter-agency working group, which is assigned to work on establishing the MPHSTF.
2.5.3. At different events the advantage of human security approach is being repeatedly advocated by the UNCT team and outreach made using different communication tools. The work will also have planned for next reporting period. During the International Conference on Aral Sea, the advantages of the Human Security Concept was sensitized also through advocacy made Mr. Yukio Takasu, UN SG’s Special Adviser on Human Security.
2.5.4. Training materials on Human Security Concept in Russian/Uzbek languages were designed and disseminated at national level in collaboration with the experts from the Academy of Public Administration under the President of Uzbekistan and involvement of International Consultant (Human Security expert).
2.5.5. The national partners were continuously invited and took part in the project events/workshops/trainings where the advantage of human security approach is being explained and presented to promote further cooperation of all partners. This is also being emphasized within the establishment of the MPHSTF. Outcome Declaration of the International Conference held in June 2018, the establishment of the Aral Sea Human Security Fund for Aral Sea is documented, which is now admitted also by other Central Asian countries.
2.6.1. The UN agencies staff are continuously taking part in the HS sessions organized by the programme. In April 2018, a series of sessions on HS were conducted by the International consultant in Tashkent for the specialists of UN agencies in Uzbekistan and UNDP projects personnel. This was done to further promoted joint planning and implantation through the application of the Human Security concept.
2.6.3. The advantage of the HS approach is extensively used by UN leadership and Programme as a concept that enables to promote people-centered, context specific, comprehensive and prevention oriented approach in addressing the Aral Sea crisis consequences. The different events are highlighting on this including during the Central Asian Eco Forum held on June 4-6, and International Conference on Aral held on June 7-8, 2018. The advance of the approach was also presented during the Aral Sea Conference pre-briefing organized by the UNCT on June 6, 2018, where apart from Mr. Takasu, UN SG’s Special Advisor on HS and Ms. Fraser, UN RC emphases on the advantage of the HU approach, a short video rolik was presented to the donor community. The High-Level event to launch the MPHSTF for Aral Sea region, which was held at UN Headquarters on 27 November 2018, the advantage of the HS concept was highlighted in addressing the multi- dimensional challenges of the Aral Sea region. The Government delegation was led by Deputy Prime Minister Kholmuradov, together with Senator Safoev, Karalkpakstan Jokarga Kenes Chairman Erniyazov, and Mr Boriy Alikhanov MP. More than 200 people attended the event, and several permanent missions, including Norway, Japan, Turkey, Kazakhstan, Nigeria and Algeria expressed their support.
